description: Specifies the Act as the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, applicable throughout India and notes the date it comes into force.
examples: A court cites BSA 2023 for rules of evidence in a trial.
Evidence collected after the commencement date is admissible under BSA.

description: Provides definitions for key terms such as evidence, fact, document, and court as used in the Act.
examples: The meaning of 'evidence' is clarified in BSA for admitting digital records.
A dispute on the definition of 'court' is settled by Section 2.

section_title: Evidence may be given of facts in issue and relevant facts
description: Allows evidence to be presented relating to facts that are in dispute or are relevant to the matter under consideration.
examples: Presenting witness testimony about the occurrence of an alleged event.
Admitting physical evidence related to a disputed contract.

section_title: Relevancy of facts forming part of same transaction
description: Establishes that facts forming part of the same transaction as the fact in issue are relevant to the case.
examples: Statements made by a suspect during commission of a crime are admissible.
Video footage showing actions during the event under investigation.

section_title: Facts which are occasion, cause or effect of facts in issue or relevant facts
description: Facts that are the cause or consequence of facts in issue or relevant facts are themselves relevant.
examples: Medical reports showing cause of injury presented in assault case.
Property damage following a disputed accident used as evidence.

section_title: Motive, preparation and previous or subsequent conduct
description: Admits facts showing motive, preparation, or conduct surrounding the fact in issue as relevant evidence.
examples: Evidence of purchase of weapons prior to a crime.
Witness testimony about suspect’s behavior after alleged offense.

section_title: Facts necessary to explain or introduce fact in issue or relevant facts
description: Includes facts that help explain or introduce other relevant facts, aiding understanding of the case.
examples: Background documents clarifying terms of a disputed contract.
Contextual information about a location where an event occurred.

section_title: Things said or done by conspirator in reference to common design
description: Statements or actions of a conspirator relating to the common plan are relevant against all conspirators.
examples: Emails exchanged planning a coordinated fraud.
Phone calls between suspects agreeing on a course of action.

section_title: When facts not otherwise relevant become relevant
description: Allows facts to be considered relevant in certain legal exceptions even if normally irrelevant.
examples: Evidence of previous good character introduced to counter bad character evidence.
Ancillary facts proved to establish authenticity of disputed documents.

section_title: Facts tending to enable Court to determine amount are relevant in suits for damages
description: Permits evidence that helps the Court assess damages or compensation to be admitted.
examples: Financial records showing loss incurred due to breach of contract.
Valuation reports submitted in personal injury claims.

description: Judgments and orders from courts of law are relevant to prove the facts decided by them.
examples: A final judgment on property ownership is used to establish title in a subsequent case.
Previous court order on custody is referenced to determine current guardianship.

description: An admission is a statement, oral or written, which suggests any inference as to any fact in issue or relevant fact.
examples: A defendant admits to being present at the scene of the crime.
A written acknowledgment of debt is treated as an admission.

description: Admissions made by agents in the course of their employment are relevant against the principal.
examples: A company’s employee admits fault during contract negotiation.
Statements by authorized agents can bind the organization.

description: Confessions made to a police officer are generally inadmissible, except under certain conditions specified in the Act.
examples: A confession made under duress to an investigating officer is excluded.
Voluntary statement recorded properly may be considered.

section_title: Confession caused by inducement, threat, or promise, to be irrelevant in criminal proceeding
description: A confession obtained through inducement, threat, or promise is not admissible in criminal trials.
examples: A suspect’s confession obtained during coercion is excluded.
Admissions made voluntarily without pressure are admissible.

section_title: Statements by persons who cannot be called as witnesses
description: Statements by persons who are dead or cannot be found may be relevant under specific circumstances.
examples: A deceased witness’s prior statement recorded under oath.
Evidence from missing persons collected through affidavits.

description: General rules on when admissions are relevant, including admissions by parties or persons interested in proceedings.
examples: Admissions by co-defendants during trial.
Statements by relatives of parties that affect interests.

description: Extent and limitations of admissibility of previous judgments in subsequent proceedings.
examples: Using prior civil judgment in a subsequent criminal case.
Prior acquittals may influence charges in related crimes.

description: Expert opinions on technical matters are relevant and admissible to assist the Court in understanding the evidence.
examples: Doctor’s opinion on cause of injury.
Forensic expert’s analysis of DNA evidence.

section_title: How much of expert’s opinion to be proved
description: Clarifies that only the facts or data forming basis of expert’s opinion need to be established in evidence.
examples: Verifying correctness of medical records underlying expert testimony.
Corroborating scientific samples analyzed by expert.

description: Certain statements made under specific circumstances are considered relevant even if they would otherwise be inadmissible.
examples: Confessions made in the presence of a magistrate.
Statements made in the course of duty like dying declarations.

description: Statements made by co-conspirators during the course of the conspiracy are admissible against other conspirators.
examples: Emails between conspirators discussing plan execution.
Phone conversations showing agreement to commit a crime.

section_title: Relevancy of statements containing opinions of witnesses
description: Witnesses' opinions may be relevant when they elucidate facts or circumstances related to the case.
examples: A witness stating they believed the accused was angry immediately before the incident.
Eyewitness expressing opinion on speed of a vehicle involved.

section_title: Relevancy of statements as to customary practices
description: Statements describing customs or usage relevant to the case are admissible.
examples: Testimony on local customs affecting contract interpretation.
Statements on trade practices to establish industry standards.

description: Evidence relating to the execution and authenticity of documents is admissible.
examples: A witness testifying that a signature is genuine.
Expert handwriting analysis confirming authenticity.

description: Documents relevant to the case may be submitted and examined in court.
examples: Contracts presented as proof of agreement.
Receipts used to verify transactions.

description: Certified copies and records from public offices are admissible as evidence.
examples: Government land records submitted in ownership disputes.
Certified birth and death certificates accepted in court.

section_title: Presumption as to genuineness of certified copies and documents
description: Certified copies of public documents are presumed to be genuine unless proved otherwise.
examples: Court accepts certified copy of an official gazette without further proof.
Certified property registration papers admitted without dispute.

description: Procedures and guidelines for the examination, cross-examination, and re-examination of witnesses.
examples: Witness questioned on material facts and challenged on inconsistencies.
Re-examination clarifies points raised during cross-examination.

section_title: Power to compel attendance of witnesses
description: Courts have authority to compel witnesses to attend and produce evidence.
examples: Issuing summons to a key witness to appear in court.
Contempt proceedings for witness refusing to appear.

description: Courts can order parties to produce relevant documents not voluntarily submitted.
examples: Ordering a party to produce email correspondence as evidence.
Requiring submission of financial statements.

description: Parties and the court have the right to inspect documents presented as evidence.
examples: Defendant inspecting contract alleged to have been breached.
Court reviewing original document to verify authenticity.

description: Under special circumstances, evidence can be presented via affidavit without oral examination.
examples: Medical reports submitted by affidavit when doctor unavailable.
Affidavit statements of witnesses out of jurisdiction.

description: Electronic evidence including digital documents, emails, and metadata are admissible under prescribed conditions.
examples: Email communications used to establish timelines.
Metadata verifying authenticity of digital contracts.

section_title: Examination of persons alleged to be mentally ill
description: Special procedures for examining mentally ill persons relevant to proceedings.
examples: Medical assessment of accused’s mental condition.
Expert testimony on competency to stand trial.

description: Measures to safeguard witnesses from intimidation or harm during evidence proceedings.
examples: Witness anonymity for protection in sensitive cases.
Secure accommodations arranged during trials.

description: Circumstances where witnesses may refuse to answer questions including privilege or self-incrimination clauses.
examples: Witness refusing to disclose confidential information.
Incriminating answers protected to prevent self-accusation.

description: Right of the opposing party to question a witness to challenge credibility or accuracy.
examples: Challenging witness inconsistencies during cross-examination.
Questioning of expert witnesses on methodology.

description: Opportunity to clarify or rebut points raised during cross-examination.
examples: Witness explaining misunderstood statements after cross.
Additional expertise introduced in re-examination of technical testimony.

description: Judges may give their opinion in cases involving complex questions of fact or law.
examples: Judge clarifies interpretation of evidentiary rules.
Chief Justice issuing opinion on novel procedural matters.

section_title: Opinion of the Court on the facts
description: The court may give its opinion on facts when required for the due administration of justice.
examples: Judge expressing opinion on conflicting witness statements.
Court providing clarity on disputed event timelines.

section_title: Judge to decide as to admissibility of evidence
description: The judge has the discretion to determine the admissibility of evidence presented during proceedings.
examples: Excluding hearsay evidence as inadmissible.
Allowing expert testimony following proper procedure.

description: Documents bearing a certificate issued by an authorized person are presumed genuine unless proven otherwise.
examples: Certified copies of government records accepted in court.
Declarations by officers confirming authenticity of public documents.

description: Evidence about the genuineness of signatures and handwriting may be provided by producing persons familiar with them.
examples: A witness testifying that a signature on a contract is genuine.
Expert analysis confirming handwriting authenticity.

description: Rules regarding the admissibility and proof of electronic signatures in evidence.
examples: A digitally signed email accepted as evidence.
Software stamps on electronic contracts verified in proceedings.

description: Official documents and electronic records maintained by public authorities are admissible as evidence.
examples: Government-issued certificates used in property disputes.
Digital archives from public departments presented in court.

description: Documents produced in the course of public actions held in official capacities are presumed genuine.
examples: Land registration documents produced by local authorities.
Official notices published in government gazette files.

description: Documents made by a public servant in executing public functions are admitted as evidence unless disproved.
examples: Inspection reports by government officers accepted as evidence.
Statements contained in official records submitted to court.

description: The court may presume the genuineness of certain documents until contrary evidence is presented.
examples: Certificates from government archives considered genuine unless challenged.
Certified copies of documents accepted on their face value.

description: Records kept in public offices and registers, including indexes and entries, are admissible as evidence.
examples: Birth and death registers accessed to prove identity.
Property registrations referenced during civil litigation.

section_title: Presumption as to maps, charts, and plans
description: Maps, charts, plans, and tracts regularly made by authorized persons are presumed genuine unless disproved.
examples: Topographical maps produced by government survey teams.
Building plans submitted for municipal approvals.

section_title: Proof of facts admitted in reply
description: Facts admitted by parties in pleadings or written statements are considered proved.
examples: Admission of debt amount in written contract.
Acknowledgement of service receipt in court documentation.

description: Admissions made orally during proceedings may be used as evidence against the admitting party.
examples: Defendant verbally acknowledging liability in court.
Statements made under oath during cross-examination.

section_title: Statements by persons who cannot be called as witnesses
description: Statements made by unavailable persons—dead, otherwise incompetent, or beyond jurisdiction—can be admitted in evidence under specific conditions.
examples: Dying declarations by victims admitted in homicide cases.
Statements recorded from missing witnesses during investigation.

section_title: Statements made in course of business
description: Records and statements kept in the ordinary course of business are admissible as evidence.
examples: Transaction logs from accounting software.
Shipping invoices regularly maintained by companies.

description: Documents which are thirty years old and produced from proper custody may be considered genuine.
examples: Historical land records over thirty years old.
Old property titles retrieved from archives.

description: Documents issued by lawful public officers and government departments are admissible.
examples: Certified copies of government orders.
Official notifications issued by regulators.

description: Electronic records, including files, emails, social media content, and digital signatures, are admissible if they fulfill prescribed conditions.
examples: Email communication used as evidence in contracts.
Digital metadata verifying the authenticity of video evidence.

section_title: Judgment of courts and public authorities
description: Decisions, orders, and judgments from courts or public authorities are evidence of the facts determined therein.
examples: Previous court ruling accepted as evidence of liability.
Regulatory orders upheld in legal disputes.

description: Documents can be proved by persons who have signed them or by witnesses to their execution.
examples: Witnesses testifying to the signing of a contract.
Handwriting experts verifying signatures.

section_title: Presumption as to documents thirty years old
description: Documents that are over thirty years old and found in proper custody are presumed genuine unless proven otherwise.
examples: Historical property titles over 30 years old admitted as proof of ownership.
Old government ledgers relied upon in inheritance disputes.

description: Certain documents regularly issued by public authorities are presumed authentic and accurate.
examples: Certified copies of birth certificates admitted as true records.
Official stamps and signatures on license documents upheld as genuine.

description: Government Gazette notifications published according to law are presumed genuine.
examples: Public notice of land acquisition published in Gazette accepted as lawful record.
Notification of tax changes published in Gazette cited in court.

section_title: Certificate of documents by public officers
description: Certificates signed by public officers relating to documents are presumed valid and accurate.
examples: Certificate by registrar on document authenticity admitted without further proof.
Government certification of maps and plans accepted as reliable.

section_title: Presumption as to maps, plans, and sketches
description: Maps, plans, drawings or charts made by authorized persons are presumed correct and authentic.
examples: Surveyor's map submitted as accurate representation of land boundaries.
Official plan of a building submitted in construction dispute.

section_title: Dealings with government and official authorities
description: Official acts, records, or notifications relating to dealings with government or authorities are presumed lawful and properly executed.
examples: Official grant of land recognized as valid title.
Tax receipts issued by government accepted as proof of payment.

section_title: Relevancy of facts concerning property in suit
description: Facts concerning possession, ownership, and dealings of property in suit are relevant to the case.
examples: Testimony about who had custody of disputed property.
Documents establishing record of ownership.

section_title: Acts or customs to prove usage or immemorial right
description: Evidence of acts or customs is relevant to establish usage or immemorial rights.
examples: Witness accounts of customary land use over decades.
Local customs presented in boundary disputes.

section_title: Admission by party to suit or another person
description: Admissions or acknowledgments made by a party or others related to the matter are relevant evidence.
examples: Acknowledgment of debt by written admission.
Statements by business partners regarding contract terms.

section_title: Fact necessary to explain or introduce relevant fact
description: Facts required to explain or introduce other evidence are themselves relevant.
examples: Contextual documents clarifying contract clauses.
Evidence showing background circumstances for disputed events.

section_title: Relevancy of facts accompanying the fact
description: Facts which naturally accompany a relevant fact and illustrate it are admissible.
examples: Witness statements describing conditions surrounding an incident.
Photographs showing environment of the alleged event.

description: Previous judgments, when relevant to the matter, may be relied upon as evidence.
examples: Final decision from earlier suit admitted as evidence.
Precedent judgments used to establish legal principles.

section_title: Facts constituting offence or evidence of motive
description: Evidence showing the commission of offence or motive of accused is relevant in prosecution.
examples: Witnesses detailing the planning of criminal act.
Discovery of tools linked to alleged offence.

section_title: Facts which show or constitute a defence
description: Facts indicating a defense or exception to alleged offence are admissible.
examples: Evidence of alibi during time of offence.
Proof of consent in cases involving assault charges.

description: Principles guiding the admissibility and weight of facts under the Act.
examples: Consideration of relevance, materiality, and admissibility by the court.
Evaluation of contradictory evidence with care.

section_title: Proof of facts by facts of general nature
description: Evidence of generally accepted facts in a locality or industry may be accepted without formal proof.
examples: Recognized trade practices admitted during commercial disputes.
Localized customs presented in property disputes.

description: Prevents parties from denying matters conclusively decided or waiving rights voluntarily.
examples: Party barred from re-litigating settled issues.
Waiver of contractual rights established through actions.

description: Forgery or imitation of handwriting or signatures is punishable and evidence of fraud.
examples: Forensic analysis detecting forged signatures.
Evidence of forged documents used in fraud.

description: Presumes the authenticity of electronic records maintained according to prescribed standards.
examples: Government-issued digital certificates accepted as authentic.
Computer-generated logs treated as prima facie evidence.

section_title: Court’s power to require production of electronic evidence
description: Courts may order production of electronic evidence relevant to the case under prescribed conditions.
examples: Demanding original email data during civil litigation.
Court-approved access to social media data for investigation.

description: Defines which party is responsible for proving particular facts and issues in a case.
examples: The prosecution must prove the guilt of the accused beyond a reasonable doubt.
The defendant may bear the burden of proving an affirmative defense.

description: Specifies certain legal presumptions that the Court may make, unless disproved by contrary evidence.
examples: Presumption of innocence of accused until proven guilty.
Presumption that official documents are authentic.

description: General provisions governing matters not specifically addressed elsewhere in the Act.
examples: Rules for admissibility of evidence not explicitly covered in specific sections.
Application of principles to new forms of evidence.

section_title: Relevancy of previous judgment in civil proceedings
description: Previous judgments are relevant for determining current disputes subject to exceptions.
examples: Using a prior suit’s decision to support ownership claim.
Excluding facts already decided in another pending case.

section_title: Relevancy of previous judgment in criminal proceedings
description: Rules for admitting previous criminal case judgments relevant to current prosecutions.
examples: Prior conviction used to establish modus operandi.
Acquittals as defense against repeated prosecution for same offence.

description: Rules governing the admissibility of evidence related to the character of parties or witnesses.
examples: Character evidence introduced to impeach witness credibility.
Evidence of good character admitted to support defense.

description: Criteria determining who is competent to testify in judicial proceedings.
examples: Minor witnesses evaluated for understanding before testifying.
Restrictions on testimony from mentally incapacitated persons.

description: Procedures and forms for administering oath or affirmation to witnesses and parties.
examples: Witness swearing to tell the truth before testimony.
Affirmations allowed for those objecting to oath on religious grounds.

description: Guidelines for conducting examination, cross-examination, and re-examination of witnesses.
examples: Initial questioning by calling party followed by the adverse party’s cross.
Re-examination to clarify issues raised during cross-examination.

description: Conditions under which evidence may be submitted by affidavit instead of oral testimony.
examples: Medical reports submitted by affidavit when doctor is unavailable.
Affidavit of a witness residing outside jurisdiction.

section_title: Powers of courts to call for production of documents
description: Courts may order any party or third party to produce documents relevant to proceedings.
examples: Court directing defendant to produce contract documents.
Subpoena issued to company for financial records.

description: Electronic records that satisfy prescribed authenticity conditions are admissible.
examples: Bank digital transaction records accepted as evidence.
Emails submitted to prove contractual communications.

description: Rules for proving authenticity of digital signatures in electronic documents.
examples: Verification of cryptographic signatures in emails.
Authentication certificates validating digital contracts.

description: Procedures for the examination of accused persons in criminal matters.
examples: Accused being asked questions in court under oath.
Mental health assessment of accused during trial.

description: Measures to protect witnesses from intimidation or harassment during trials.
examples: Granting witness anonymity in sensitive cases.
Providing security to key prosecution witnesses.

description: Courts have the authority to summon parties or witnesses to appear or produce documents.
examples: Issuance of summons to a reluctant witness.
Order for a party to appear before court.

description: Guidelines and powers relating to collecting and recording evidence in trials.
examples: Recording witness statements under oath.
Collection of physical evidence from crime scenes.

description: Every accused is presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond reasonable doubt.
examples: Defendant granted benefit of doubt in uncertain cases.
No punishment without conclusive evidence of offence.

description: Rules for admitting confessions made by accused persons in evidence.
examples: Voluntary confession taken before magistrate admitted.
Confession obtained under threat excluded as evidence.

description: Evidence obtained through illegal means or violation of constitutional rights is inadmissible.
examples: Confessions made under torture excluded from trial.
Evidence seized without proper warrant inadmissible.

description: Courts may take judicial notice of facts of common knowledge or not subject to reasonable dispute.
examples: Recognition of national holidays without proof.
Public facts like sunrise and sunset times taken as known.

description: Evidence that does not relate to the matter in issue is not admissible.
examples: Testimony about unrelated past criminal history excluded.
Irrelevant hearsay statements dismissed by the court.

description: Regulates the order and manner in which evidence is presented in court.
examples: Prosecution presents its evidence before the defense.
Parties lead witnesses in direct and cross-examination.

description: At the close of evidence, parties may summarize key points before final arguments.
examples: Attorney summarizing inconsistencies in evidence.
Highlighting admissions and contradictions in testimony.

description: Permits use of electronic evidence in courts subject to verification and proper standards.
examples: Digital signatures in e-contracts accepted by courts.
Video footage stored on digital devices admitted as proof.

description: Specifies how electronic evidence should be collected, preserved, and presented to court.
examples: Following chain-of-custody rules for digital evidence.
Ensuring integrity of electronic data during investigation.

description: Guidelines on how courts should interpret and weigh different kinds of evidence.
examples: Giving greater weight to direct eyewitness testimony.
Evaluating circumstantial evidence with caution.

description: Defines the methods for establishing legal relationships like marriage, parentage, or guardianship.
examples: Birth certificates admitted to prove parentage.
Marriage registration documents used to establish spousal relationship.

description: Specifies evidence required to prove a person's death in legal proceedings.
examples: Official death certificates admitted as conclusive proof.
Testimony of last known whereabouts prior to disappearance.

section_title: Presumption as to existence of certain facts
description: Certain facts are presumed to exist unless disproved by evidence.
examples: Presumption that documents properly certified are correct.
Presumption of legal guardian’s authority over minor.

description: Specifies procedures for proving authenticity and integrity of digitally stored evidence.
examples: Demonstrating the origin and integrity of digital documents.
Validating timestamps on electronic records.

description: Rules governing the admissibility and verification of electronic signatures in legal matters.
examples: Verification of digital certificates accompanying contracts.
Use of cryptographic methods to authenticate signatures.

description: Measures for the safeguarding of witnesses against threats or harassment during trials.
examples: Granting anonymity to witnesses in sensitive cases.
Providing police protection to key witnesses.

description: Power of the Court to examine any witness on any matter relevant to the case.
examples: Judge questioning a witness to clarify testimony.
Court eliciting information directly from expert witness.

description: Criteria for determining whether a witness is competent to testify.
examples: Assessing mental capacity of witness before allowing testimony.
Limiting testimony of children based on understanding.

description: The initial examination of a witness conducted by the party who called the witness.
examples: Prosecutor questioning a witness about the facts of the case.
Plaintiff examining a witness to establish claim.

description: The examination of a witness by the opposing party to test credibility and truthfulness.
examples: Defence counsel questioning prosecution witness to find contradictions.
Challenging discrepancies in eyewitness accounts.

description: Further questioning of a witness by the party who called them, aimed at clarifying issues raised during cross-examination.
examples: Witness explaining ambiguous statements made in cross-examination.
Addressing new points raised by opposing counsel.

description: A witness who is adverse or reluctant to the party who called them may be declared hostile and subjected to crossexamination.
examples: Witness giving testimony unfavourable to the calling party.
Judge permitting cross-examination by calling party after hostile declaration.

section_title: Power to order attendance of witnesses
description: Courts can order witnesses to attend and give evidence when necessary.
examples: Issuing summons to reluctant witness.
Penalties for failing to appear in court as ordered.

description: Courts can compel the production of documents necessary for the proper adjudication of the case.
examples: Court ordering a company to submit financial records.
Demanding contract copies for examination during litigation.

description: The right of parties or the court to inspect documents presented as evidence.
examples: Examining original will to verify authenticity.
Reviewing photographs submitted during trial.

description: Conditions under which affidavits are admissible as evidence.
examples: Submitting notarized exception statements.
Affidavits filed in lieu of witness testimony.

description: Guidelines for admissibility of electronic documents and data in legal proceedings.
examples: Admitting digital contracts signed with valid electronic signatures.
Use of CCTV footage stored in digital format.

description: Certification of electronic records pursuant to prescribed standards for admissibility.
examples: Official seal certifying authenticity of digital records.
Trusted timestamping of submitted electronic evidence.

section_title: Power to issue warrant for possession of evidence
description: Courts can issue orders to seize evidence necessary for investigation or trial.
examples: Warrant to seize computers containing digital evidence.
Order for confiscation of forged documents.

section_title: Protection of accused during evidence collection
description: Safeguards to ensure accused persons’ rights during evidence gathering.
examples: Ensuring medical examiners obtain consent before examinations.
Protecting privacy during collection of samples.

section_title: Rajiv Gandhi Institute for Contemporary Studies
description: Provision establishing the Rajiv Gandhi Institute for Contemporary Studies.
examples: Institute conducting research on evidence law reforms.
Training programs for legal professionals.

description: Details regarding amendments to existing laws and repeal of prior provisions.
examples: Repealing outdated Evidence Act provisions.
Implementing new evidence standards under BSA.

description: Miscellaneous provisions related to the interpretation and application of the Act.
examples: Rules of construction for ambiguous clauses.
Provisions relating to jurisdiction and application.

description: Provides for repeal of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, while saving certain actions and proceedings under previous laws.
examples: Pending cases under the prior Evidence Act continue subject to old provisions.
Certain rights and liabilities preserved despite repeal.

description: Clarifies interpretation of commonly used terms throughout the Act to ensure consistent understanding.
examples: Definition of terms such as 'court', 'document', and 'fact'.
Guidelines on gender-neutral and singular/plural usage.

description: Presumes electronic evidence to be genuine if produced in accordance with prescribed conditions unless disproved.
examples: Digital contracts accepted as genuine upon proper certification.
Electronic transaction logs presumed valid.

description: Outlines conditions for the admissibility of electronic records as evidence.
examples: Email communications admitted upon verification of source.
Electronic health records used as proof of treatment.

description: Court’s authority to review documents and evidence submitted during proceedings.
examples: Reconsideration of submitted expert reports.
Direction to produce additional clarifying documents.

description: Specifies protocols for collecting, preserving, and presenting electronic evidence.
examples: Ensuring chain of custody in digital forensics.
Admission of metadata as corroborating evidence.

description: Safeguards individuals against being compelled to incriminate themselves during evidence proceedings.
examples: Witness exercising right to remain silent.
Non-admissibility of forced confessions.

description: Restrictions and conditions for admitting evidence regarding character of persons involved.
examples: Character evidence admitted only when relevant to the case.
Restrictions on use of bad character evidence.

description: Allows proof of authenticity of handwriting and voice through expert testimony or familiarity evidence.
examples: Expert calligraphy expert verifying signatures.
Familiar witnesses confirming voice recordings.

description: Recognizes multiple lawful means to prove facts including oral, documentary, and electronic evidence.
examples: Using emails alongside oral witness testimony.
Admission of contracts in both paper and digital forms.

description: Provides authority to summons witnesses and conduct their examination during judicial proceedings.
examples: Issuing a summons to an eyewitness to appear in court.
Conducting examination in chief and cross-examination of witnesses.

description: Allows courts to clarify ambiguous or vague statements made during testimony or evidence presentation.
examples: Requesting the witness to elaborate on unclear answers.
Seeking explanation for contradictory evidence.

section_title: Power to examine person accused of offence
description: Empowers the court or authorized officer to examine the accused regarding the allegations.
examples: Judge questioning accused to confirm alibi.
Medical examination ordered to determine fitness for trial.

description: Grants the accused or defense the right to cross-examine prosecution witnesses.
examples: Defense counsel asking probing questions to challenge witness credibility.
Highlighting inconsistencies in testimony during cross-examination.

description: Outlines provisions to safeguard witnesses from threats, intimidation, or harm.
examples: Granting anonymity to vulnerable witnesses.
Providing police protection during high-profile cases.

description: Empowers judges to admit or exclude evidence based on relevance, reliability, and legal standards.
examples: Excluding irrelevant circumstantial evidence.
Admitting authenticated digital records.

description: Sets guidelines for the presentation and questioning of expert witnesses during trials.
examples: Expert testifies on forensic analysis methods.
Cross-examination focuses on expert’s qualifications and methodology.

description: Formalizes the acceptance of scientific tests, experiments, and reports as evidence.
examples: DNA analysis results admitted in a criminal case.
Chemical residue tests submitted during prosecution.

description: Allows admission of audio-visual recordings as evidence where certified and relevant.
examples: CCTV footage admitted to establish presence at crime scene.
Recorded telephone conversations used to prove intent.

description: Permits courts to authorize inspection of relevant places or objects connected to the case.
examples: Visit to alleged accident site to verify conditions.
Inspection of seized goods in store’s warehouse.

description: Evidence showing the motive behind an act is relevant to proving the commission of the act.
examples: Showing financial difficulties as motive for embezzlement.
Demonstrating prior disputes as motive for assault.

description: Admissions relating to the general character of a person are relevant in proceedings.
examples: Admission of dishonest nature in fraud cases.
Acknowledgment of reputation for violence in assault cases.

description: Parties may be required to produce documents relevant to the matter in proceedings.
examples: Order to produce contract documents in breach of contract suit.
Request for company records during fraud investigation.

description: Proof of the contents of a document can be given by the document itself or by oral evidence where admissible.
examples: Reading aloud contract clauses in court.
Using copies of original documents when originals are unavailable.

description: Public documents and their certified copies are admissible and presumed genuine unless disproved.
examples: Certified property register entries accepted as evidence.
Certified extracts from government archives.

description: Official acts done in accordance with law are presumed valid unless proven otherwise.
examples: Presumption of validity of court orders.
Presumption of proper execution of government procedures.

section_title: Proof of foreign laws and judgments
description: Foreign laws and judgments may be proved by expert opinion or diplomatic documents.
examples: Expert testimony on foreign commercial regulations.
Certified copies of foreign court rulings.

section_title: Admissibility of evidence relating to foreign matters
description: Evidence regarding foreign laws, customs, or events may be admitted where relevant.
examples: Evidence of international contracts in cross-border disputes.
Testimony on foreign transactions affecting case.

section_title: Evidence of facts admitted under special circumstances
description: Certain facts admitted by parties under specific colloquy or circumstances are admitted in evidence.
examples: Admissions made during plea bargaining.
Statements made under formal deposition procedures.

section_title: Judgment as evidence of facts decided
description: Judgments of courts are evidence of matters decided therein but not evidence for other facts.
examples: Proven guilt in previous case presented in sentencing.
Cascade effect of civil judgments in related suits.

description: Evidence obtained through violation of constitutional rights or illegal means shall be excluded.
examples: Forcibly obtained confessions excluded from trial.
Illegally seized documents inadmissible as evidence.

description: Irrelevant facts that do not assist in proving points at issue shall not be considered.
examples: Ignoring unrelated personal background evidence.
Excluding anecdotal stories unrelated to charges.

description: Electronic evidence shall be admissible if it conforms to prescribed procedures for authenticity and integrity.
examples: E-mails with proper digital signatures admitted.
Surveillance footage stored digitally used in prosecution.

section_title: Exclusion of documents without proper authentication
description: Documents lacking prescribed authentication shall not be admitted in evidence.
examples: Unauthenticated scanned documents excluded.
Unsigned electronic records rejected.

description: Rules governing the proof of authenticity and accuracy of electronic records.
examples: Certificates verifying data integrity of electronic documents.
Chain of custody for electronical evidence maintained.

description: Courts may take judicial notice of digital documents meeting specified criteria without requiring formal proof.
examples: Considering government web publications as evidence.
Accepting digital government notifications.

description: Electronic data messages sent and received in due course are admissible as evidence.
examples: Instant messages exchanged related to contractual terms.
Texts submitted to show communication timeline.

description: Presumption of genuineness applies to electronic messages transmitted through legitimate systems.
examples: Emails from official accounts presumed authentic.
System-generated alerts taken as valid.

section_title: Disclosure of contents of electronic records
description: Conditions under which the contents of electronic records can be disclosed in proceedings.
examples: Court order for decryption of encrypted files.
Access granted to emails in investigation.

description: General rules governing the application and interpretation of the Act.
examples: Application of rules to all courts except specified tribunals.
Clarifications on continuing validity of earlier provisions.
